I highly believe in giving things a fair chance before I throw my chips into a bowl, so, after having actually played it, I can say that this game is rather callous to Transgendered issues, at least over the course of the first two routes (if there is places it does this better, please let me know)

You can generally tell what is going to happen long before it does. Since each character tells you precisely what they include (How many endings, what types of strangeness they will encounter) any real surprise is removed before it can sink in. You're left scrolling through lives that you can figure out precisely where they may be going (accurately) long before they get there. After about an hour, you start reading the text simply to confirm you were invariably right.

The game is insensitive, and honestly I'm a bit hurt that someone could even make something like this. The artists have deleted several threads filled with honest criticism of the title, but they are also at the same time incredibly helpful both to me and others. They are just trying to stand by the game they made.

I find myself genuinely conflicted, because distasteful art is still art. Even if I think what they show here is 'bad', it's designed with someone else in mind, and I wonder if that person really deserves for me to demonize their fun. In any case, I do not personally recommend this game to others. If this is your sort of thing, you could do well to wait for a good sale in any case.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My earlier review was too long for Steam, so here’s the abridged version.

GBDNATE purports to be a Visual Novel about a couple of researchers who devise a serum that changes the gender of anyone exposed to it. A lab accident occurs, hilarity (in theory) then ensues, and all of the exposed people have to cope with the ramifications of the gender swap.

What The Ad Copy Leads You To Believe: This is a zany, gender-bender comedy extravaganza along the lines of Ranma 1/2 that portrays the hilarity of a diverse cast of characters having to adjust ‘to wearing a bra in the morning’ (per the devs). That said, the title is also allegedly sensitive to the many difficulties transgendered individuals face in modern society.

What The Title Actually Is: The extended, misogynistic, self-insert fetish fanwank of two boys who wish they were hot lesbians, and whose comprehension of gender issues and cultural sensitivity lies slightly below that of Chris Brown.

How Much Have I Played: Every route of every character thus far released, from Yael to their latest character, Nadine.

As someone on the discussion boards pointed out, a Visual Novel needs to have: Art, Story and Gameplay. GBDNATE is wanting in all three categories.

The ART in GBDNATE has been called “anime style”, and that style is fairly common for VNs. The style itself would work, if not for problems with:

Basic Anatomy - Even by anime standards, the characters’ proportions are grotesque. Hands and feet are awkwardly avoided or poorly drawn. Character poses (especially Steph) would require breaking the character’s spine.

Clothing - The artist doesn’t seem to know how cloth hangs on the human body, nor how light shines on it. He also thinks every woman dresses like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Perspective - Backgrounds defy the rules of perspective drawing, and the characters (who are flatly drawn) appear simultaneously in front of and behind other objects.

Eye Bubbles - The characters’ eyes look more like lizard eyes than eyes with light reflections.

I’d encourage anyone who wants to see the art to look at the screenshots or download the demo.

The STORY in GBDNATE is not one story where you play the character you want. GBDNATE is implemented as separate (8 now, 13 total planned) stories that have some events (the explosion) in common, but otherwise contain too many inconsistencies to be deemed a perspective shift.

The first seven routes have none of the Setup / Conflict / Resolution narrative structure of a VN at all, so they read as “stuff happens until it stops”. The eighth route (Nadine) is the only route with a coherent narrative.

The characters in GBDNATE are flat and largely indistinguishable. Yael and Nadine are the most coherent characters; Lynn and Dina are the developers’ Mary Sues (with all the problems thus engendered), while the rest of the characters are forgettable. They all talk and think with the same narrative voice, despite differences in age, gender, education, social standing and anything else.

Good character ensemble humor comes from the interplay of different, well-defined personalities (think Rumiko Takahashi or Seinfeld), but since the characters are poorly (often inconsistently) defined, there’s no humor in their interaction. They’re just lifeless boob joke generators, and nothing more.

With no humor, a fanwank title like GBDNATE should at least have a titilation factor, but all the sex scenes are rendered as follows:

…
……
………
“Was it good for you?”

Unless one finds ellipses to be erotic, there’s no titillation to be had in GBDNATE. The characters masturbate more than they connect with each other anyway (Yael actually sets a flag for this, sadly).

In terms of the writing, the developers are violating the first rule of writing: “Write what you know”. Anyone with genuine experience in the sciences, technology, the law, sex or anything else will find much to bang their head on the desk over.

Nadine’s route was especially bad. It strayed into the realms of science, computer hacking & security, legality, criminal investigations, corporate business culture, investing, and a variety of other fields in which the developers clearly have no knowledge or experience. Even the background art will make any computer-savvy player twitch.

Mechanically, the writing is just not good. Tenses drift, continuity errors abound in all routes, there are plenty of spelling and grammar errors - it’s a hot mess. It’s not as hilariously bad as “My Immortal”, but it’s definitely a distraction in a format that relies on writing to convey 95% of the content.

Nadine’s route was the worst offender in this category as well. My impression was that someone had spell-checked the hell out of it, but nobody ever sat down to proofread it with a red pen. Again, in a text-centric medium, solid editing is just as important as basic code testing.

GAMEPLAY: Up until Nadine’s route, there is none. The first seven routes are nothing more than Choose Your Adventure novels (with very few choices). By making a choice, you choose which path the narrative goes down. What few choices you get often have no bearing on the content to which they lead, which means that making a single choice of “Stay At Work” leads inexorably to the Lesbian Catgirl Ending of that route. Things like sexual orientation are determined by getting haircuts and eating nachos.

There are no skills to master, there are no meaningful status flags to set, there is no endgame to navigate, there are no deductions to make. In the first seven routes, there simply is no gameplay at all.

They tried to change this in the Nadine route (which ends with a watered-down Phoenix Wright knockoff), but the only real “gameplay” here is in asking a few common sense questions in the right order. At no point is any information from the rest of the game required to navigate the endgame, and it’s quite possible to reach the optimal ending having never seen the rest of the story that leads up to it.

Still, as badly executed and derivative as it was, I’ll give them credit for the attempt. It’s a positive sign that after over a year of being told that their title has no gameplay, they actually gave it a try in one route.

CODE QUALITY: While not normally relevant in a review, I do have a couple of comments because of two factors:

The developers didn’t write their own VN engine; they’re using a free one called RenPy.
The developers are charging premium dollars ($25 as of this writing) for their title.

Given that the developers are charging premium dollars for a title that’s just a script running on someone else’s engine, it better be a pretty amazing script.

Thing is, it’s not.  GBDNATE is an absolutely appalling pile of spaghetti code that a) would not be accepted in a Comp101 class, and b) taps into almost none of the RenPy engine’s capabilities.

There are far more robust RenPy games available for free on the RenPy website. There are far more robust RenPy games right here on Steam for far less money. GBDNATE simply is not implemented well, nor is it worthy of the ridiculous price tag hung upon it.

FINAL SUMMARY:

GBDNATE is a bad title, plain and simple.

Do I recommend it? Well, if you share the developers’ fetishes, I’ll recommend that you download the free demo. If you like that, you’ll probably like the rest of it enough to buy it if they ever put a realistic price on it: say, $6.99 (the price of a trade paperback). It’s not worth any more than that, in my opinion.

I’ve been asked by several people if GBDNATE is a “so bad it’s good” title. In my opinion, it’s not. It’s just dull and tediously bad, with mediocre art and way too many 5th grade boob jokes.

reviewText:
What this game is:

Gender Bender DNA Twister Extreme is a light-hearted story about a science experiment gone wrong that transforms several people into the opposite sex. It also covers the consequences and aftermath of the accident in several of the newer characters.

Pros:

1. Funny, witty, silly, and occaisionally hits the mark on the emotional or profound.
2. Likeable characters
3. A soundtrack that grows on you after a while and is well utilitized during Dan's story

Cons:

1. Typos in the text. After 12 characters and multiple releases, this shouldn't be happening. Especially in the older content.
2. Incorrect name plates for characters involved in their own storylines and appearing in stories prior to their own. I'd really like to see this get fixed on account that it's distracting and a spoiler.
3. Character selection is not grouped or organized by plot timeline. While it's nice to be able to pick any character that looks interesting, there's a definite order for them to be played in for the plot to make sense. At the very least the loading screen should start up on Dina or Lynn since either of them play out the baseline story.

Conclusion:

GBDNATE is a fun little bit of entertainment. It doesn't try to dive into the deep emotional and physical hardships transpeople experience everyday. At the same time it doesn't minimize them either. It simply does two things- It tries to answer the question what if this happened. And conveys the simple message that identity, gender or otherwise, is a part of a person's mind and heart- not their body.

If you're debating whether or not this is for you: This game is in no way even trying to be a realistic representation of being transgender. This is a fetish game, and one that's appealing to a very niche audience. If you're looking for a game about the life of transgender individuals, this isn't it; if you're looking for a normal-ish porn game, this isn't it, I would reccomend Huniepop though.
However, if transformation fetishes apply to you, be it breast expansion, animal transformation or gender swapping, this game is most certainly for you.

While it isn't cheap and the artwork doesn't even come close to standing up to a game such as Huniepop, it is actually fairly amusing for a visual novel. A lot of people I see talking about it ask why you wouldn't just on deviantart to find this; and to that, I challenge you to find anything nearly as vast or complete. Many of the characters have more than 5 endings to find. I’ve given this game a good chance, getting through several story-lines with multiple characters, and I can honestly say that it has captivated me into wanting to play more. Alot of it is fan service, I will admit, but the amount of individual scenes, characters, personalities, and stories that manage to link up to one-another in some fashion is to me mind boggling.
I recommend this game to anyone who does have even minor interests in gender transformation, anthropomorphic transformation, chest expansion, or same sex romances/multiple romances. Also, I highly recommend this for someone who loves a complex story tree that branches out into so many different avenue but still manages to keep the overall story intact.
Yes, I will admit that the art and stories are not on par with that of Nekopara or If My Heart Had Wings, but it is a very close second to me. Though the story is leagues ahead from such trash as the Sakura Spirit/Angles...
Give the Gender Bender a whirl, I believe in time you’ll come to enjoy the transformation as much as the characters. I look forward to the Rose story arch and hope to see more for this developer in the future. Awesome job guy!
As a P.S. to those who are interested (or care), I’m a woman and I still enjoy this game. It’s nice to think of guys being able to see the world from our point of view.

Edit 1: It has been a long while since I have played as I was waiting for the Russell update, then life happened and I was pleasantly surprised  by the addition of Aleanne.
First, let me say that the game does get better as you play it! Not only in story, but in art as well. You can see the artist improve with each new update and I find it prenominal. Like watching an artists progression only through a story telling media.
I will admit that it would be nice to see the entire game redone to fit the new and improved work, but that would be asking for an almost complete overhaul every time the game is updated. Not feasible in the slightest with the pittance that is being charged for this game.
Second, I hate to say that Aleanne is a little disappointing; with a story that feels rushed and a good deal of typos and incongruities, it’s not as captivating as the previous. But then I assume it would be hard to follow up after Russell, which is a really fun pit of story/puzzle.
Regardless, this bit of negative does not tarnish the game as a whole. It is still a wonderful game that will captivate and keep you going for a lot longer than most of the story games out there. I still highly recommend this game and look forward to the Scarlett update and any others that may follow. Keep going Dev, you’re doing amazingly despite what a few haters may think!

Cons I've seen
- Minor Spelling/gramtical errors

Pros I've seen
- Good stories that can become emotional
- characters aren't 2D on their emotions
- Imersive 1st person perspective that is also shown from a 3rd person view allowing you to be in the mind of the character while not actually being the charater.

I'd love to see these stories continue and hopefully as it develops we'll be seeing more characters and additions to the stories as what happens later down the road.

This game is a prime example of something good coming out of Steam Greenlight.
Both action-packed and strategic, it is a rare combination for a game made by indie developers.

The art style really is impeccible, not like anything I have seen before, and it is one of the main points that led me to purchase this game.

Although I have not finished this astounding game yet, I can safely say that so far It has been a thought-provoking adventure into the future possibilites of gender-swapping scientific research.

Needless to say, not only the art is good about this game. In a game like this where writing is key, I must say it fits the lock rather snug. I find the writing absolutely inspiring, and would like to compliment the lead writer.

Overall, for the few hours I have played of this game, I am greatly looking forward to what the developers will expand upon.
I believe this game is one I will still be playing for many weeks.

Overall, aside from a few flaws, I would highly recommend this videogame and rate it an 8.8/10.
